p: 4. Mineness. The being that I am always concerned about is, in every instance, mine. Ex-sistence is not a genus that encompasses things in the world. (Such things do not and cannot have concern—or lack of concern—for themselves.) The fact that ex-sistence is “always mine”—whoever the person is, ex-sistence is always his or her very own exsistence— entails that we must always use a personal pronoun: “I,” “you,” etc., when speaking of ex-sistence.¶
